# Videos from session #04

![][13]![][14]

 _Solidity: Solidity-by-feature + solc + ganache + truffle_

We held our 4th session - on Solidity - a few days ago, on Tuesday
evening at Chainstack. We covered features of Solidity as a programming
language, as well as a few development tools used to work with Solidity
- solc, truffle, and ganache.

We've previously posted a [round up summary][15] about the session. This
post is about the videos that we have recorded during the session.

## The videos

ðŸŽž [Intro][16]

ðŸŽž [Recap][17]

ðŸŽž [Solidity-by-feature][18]

ðŸŽž [solc][19]

ðŸŽž [ganache][20]

ðŸŽž [truffle][21]

ðŸŽž [Next][22]

## Thanks

A big thanks to Zi Hui & [Wing][23] for helping with the recordings, to
[Ashlie][24] from [Chainstack][25], and Dennis from [Acronis][26]

Also thanks to EngineersSG, especially [Michael Cheng][27], for their
excellent [DIY tech meetup recording guide][28] without which we would
probably have no recordings!

## News

All of our sessions are now available on [Engineers.SG][29]!

[ ![All Episodes on Engineers.SG][30] ][31]

For those of you who have not heard of them before:

> Engineers.SG is a not-for-profit community initiative created to help
document the Singapore tech and startup scene.

>

> Created to answer the question, "where are the engineers in
Singapore?", Engineers.SG seeks to be the place for anyone to get to
know, learn and interact with the Singapore tech community. On the site,
you can find a curated list of videos recording of local tech meetups
and events.

Chances are, if you go to a tech meetup in Singapore, and it is being
recorded, the Engineers.SG crew is behind it. We're stoked to be on
board with them!

[DApps Dev Club on Engineers.SG][32]

## Reflections

AV is an area in which we started this series off with close to zero
expertise, and we have been constantly learning.

Our journey so far:

When we recorded the first session, we found that the video framerate
was very low, to the point that it was choppy, and we managed to figure
out what was causing that and fix it in time for the second session.
However, the volume that was recorded was unusually low, and the
recorded videos were barely audible. We weren't able to fix this in
post-processing without a lot of noise and distortions, and this problem
persisted in both sessions 2 and 3.

However, in time for session 4, we managed to work out [how to](https://www.playgroundfx.com/blog/forex-trading-how-to/) record at
a higher volume, without picking up too much background noise, and thus
were able to adjust the volume levels in post processing. The quality of
the videos that have we have for this session are the best that we have
had to date, and quite frankly _good enough_. So in remaining sessions,
we aim to maintain this quality that we have achieved.

Thanks to [Michael Cheng][33] of [Engineers.SG][29] for his help with
figuring out the post-processing. In particular, the Engineers.SG git
wiki - which we have already been using as a reference for our hardware
purchase and connection set ups - also happens to contain some [handy
scripts][34] which we used to do things better this time around.

Thanks to Dennis from [Acronis][35] for his hands-on support in helping
out with adjusting the settings and connection configuration for the
audio that allowed the recorded audio to have a **much better** signal-
to-noise ratio than we had previously achieved.

## Next session

RSVPs are now open - please let us know if you're attending, as it helps
us plan for seating, ordering F&B, etc:

[**RSVP** on eventbrite][36]

See you all again soon!
